comments.comment: ApplicableEarningsPeriod RUle

comments.author: Alberto Galende
comments.comment: As we talked, I have to implement a fix to solve the problem with the ApplicableEarningsPeriod Rule.

comments.author: Gil Matias

comments.author: Gil Matias
comments.comment:
I think this is a bit overkill. Why are we recalculating this every time we do a Get dates?
Why dont we just update the start dates when new periods are added and remove the setters?

comments.author: Alberto Galende
comments.comment: As this is a calculated field, it's useless (seems that it's not because breaks the ApplicableEarningPeriod) to have to update these fields every time we add a new AbsencePeriod. We shouldn't be storing in DB values that are always calculated. We were doing that before. There is gonna be a new FAB to reduce this technical debt to create a query to get these dates from the DB instead of calculating them sorting the list (even if this is a small list, it's not common to have a lot of AbsencePeriods in the same LeaveRequest) to improve the performance.

comments.author: Gil Matias
comments.comment: I am ok with that

comments.author: Aisling Clinch
comments.comment: Can we add tests for these?

comments.author: Aisling Clinch
comments.comment: Rather than doing this, could we not just call _getSortedAbsencePeriods(false);_ & then get the first object in the list? _return ascendingPeriods.isEmpty() ? DateTime.getLowDate() : ascendingPeriods.get(0).getEndDate();_

comments.comment: Shame on me\! cheers
